_source.name: Spondylocostal Dysostosis
_source.commonSymptoms: Spondylocostal dysostosis is an inherited skeletal disorder affecting dogs. Puppies with this condition are born dead or die shortly after birth. Affected puppies have multiple skeletal abnormalities of the spinal column and ribs and their hindquarters are less developed than their forequarters. These abnormalities cause the spinal column to be shortened and give them a comma-like shape. They may also display other congenital abnormalities such as umbilical hernias and cleft palates.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the HES7 gene will reliably determine whether a dog is a genetic carrier of spondylocostal dysostosis. Spondylocostal dysostosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in dogs meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier dogs do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected pups. Each pup that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the HES7 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected pups, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Dogs that are not carriers of the mutation have no increased risk of having affected pups.
references: Willet CE, Makara M, Reppas G, Tsoukalas G, Malik R, Haase B, Wade CM. Canine disorder mirrors human disease: exonic deletion in HES7 causes autosomal recessive spondylocostal dysostosis in miniature Schnauzer dogs. PLoS One. 2015 Feb 6;10(2):e0117055. [PubMed: 25659135](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25659135)

_source.name: Van Den Ende-Gupta Syndrome
_source.commonSymptoms: Van den Ende-Gupta syndrome is an inherited bone disorder affecting dogs. Affected puppies are born with multiple skeletal abnormalities of which an underbite is most notable. They also have small eyes and bowed hind legs. Skeletal changes in the legs make dogs prone to luxation of the knees and occasionally elbows. While affected dogs live normal lives, they are prone to osteoarthritis of the knees and vertebrae.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the SCARF2 gene will reliably determine whether a dog is a genetic carrier of Van den Ende-Gupta syndrome. Van den Ende-Gupta syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in dogs meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier dogs do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected pups. Each pup that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the SCARF2 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected pups, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Dogs that are not carriers of the mutation have no increased risk of having affected pups.
references: Hytönen MK, Arumilli M, Lappalainen AK, Owczarek-Lipska M, Jagannathan V, Hundi S, Salmela E, Venta P, Sarkiala E, Jokinen T, Gorgas D, Kere J, Nieminen P, Drögemüller C, Lohi H. Molecular Characterization of Three Canine Models of Human Rare Bone Diseases: Caffey, van den Ende-Gupta, and Raine Syndromes. PLoS Genet. 2016 May 17;12(5):e1006037. [PubMed: 27187611](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27187611)

_source.name: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Maine Coon Type) (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Maine coon type) is an inherited disorder of the heart affecting cats. This disease shows incomplete penetrance, meaning that not all cats at risk (those with one or two copies of the mutation) will develop the disease. Affected cats are typically diagnosed between 13-40 months of age via an echocardiogram performed by a veterinary cardiologist. On echocardiogram, the wall of the heart, specifically the left ventricular wall, is thickened. Thickening of the ventricular wall affects the ability of the heart to fill with blood and narrows the outflow tract resulting in poor blood flow. Affected male cats are typically diagnosed earlier and have more severe disease than female cats. Disease progression varies between cats with most cats progressing to heart failure while less often, some cats never develop symptoms. Signs of heart disease include exercise intolerance, fatigue, coughing, difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, fainting, sudden painful, rear paralysis, and sudden death. Most cats with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy die from congestive heart failure or die suddenly within 3-7 months of diagnosis. Different disease genes and environmental factors play a role the development of dilated cardiomyopathy in cats. This mutation demonstrates incomplete penetrance, with about 6%-18% of heterozygous cats (cats with one copy of the mutation) and 58%-80% of homozygous cats (cats with two copies of the mutation) eventually developing the disease.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the MYBPC3 gene will reliably determine the number of copies of the hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) mutation in cats.  Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Maine coon type) is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner in cats meaning that that they only need to inherit one copy of the mutated gene to be at an increased risk of developing the disease. Thus, cats that have one or two mutant copies of the gene are considered at-risk for HCM. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. Because symptoms do not appear until adulthood and because the mutation shows incomplete penetrance, genetic testing should be performed before breeding. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of cats known to have the mutation is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens.  Therefore, not all cats with this disease will have the same genetic mutation. Some kittens that inherit two copies of the mutation may die in utero resulting in smaller litter sizes.
references: Freeman LM, Rush JE, Stern JA, Huggins GS, Maron MS. Feline Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: A Spontaneous Large Animal Model of Human HCM. Cardiol Res. 2017 Aug;8(4):139-142. [PubMed:28868097](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28868097)

A cardiac myosin binding protein C mutation in the Maine Coon cat with familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Hum Mol Genet. 2005 Dec 1;14(23):3587-93. [PubMed: 16236761](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16236761)

Rush JE, Freeman LM, Fenollosa NK, Brown DJ. Population and survival characteristics of cats with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: 260 cases (1990-1999). J Am Vet Med Assoc. 2002 Jan 15;220(2):202-7. [PubMed: 12126131](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12126131)

_source.name: Hypotrichosis with Short Life Expectancy (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Hypotrichosis with short life expectancy (HSLE) is an inherited disease affecting hair growth and immune system function in Birman cats. Affected kittens are born without hair and experience a reduced lifespan secondary to chronic or recurring infections., Affected kittens fail to develop the main organ of the lymphatic system known as the  thymus which serves an important role in the development of T-lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell (T-cell). Lack of mature T-cells predisposes affected cats to severe and recurrent infections, most commonly of the skin, digestive system, and respiratory system. Affected cats typically die or are euthanized by 8 months of age due to severe complications related to infection and poor quality of life. In one study, 3.2% of Birman cats were carriers of the FOXN1 mutation.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the FOXN1 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of hypotrichosis with short life expectancy.  This form of hypotrichosis with immunodysfunction is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the FOXN1 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. A normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Abitbol M, Bossé P, Thomas A, Tiret L. A deletion in FOXN1 is associated with a syndrome characterized by congenital hypotrichosis and short life expectancy in Birman cats. PLoS One. 2015 Mar 17;10(3):e0120668. [PubMed PMID: 25781316](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25781316)

_source.name: ABC Blood Group System (Cat)
_source.detailedSummary: Each blood group system consists of a set of blood types, each of which corresponds to a particular antigen (usually a glycoprotein) on the surface of red blood cells. The different types within a system are the result of the action of different alleles at a locus that usually encodes an enzyme that catalyzes the creation of the feature of the glycoprotein unique to that blood type. In domestic cats, the CMAH gene is responsible for the different blood groups. The ABC blood group system consists of the three serotypes A, B and C (also called AB). Mismatches can cause acute hemolytic transfusion reactions and hemolysis of the newborn (neonatal isoerythrolysis, NI). As blood types B and C are inherited recessively to A, breeders need to know the genotype to predict blood types in offspring and avoid NI. Cats possess naturally occurring antibodies against the blood antigens that they lack. Blood type B cats have strong antibodies against A and blood type A cats have weak antibodies against B, while blood type C cats have no antibodies since they express both A and B antigens. Kittens that are A or C blood types will receive antibodies against their own blood type during nursing to a blood type B mother causing hemolysis in the kitten, which leads to lethargy, tachycardia, tachypnea, collapse, and death.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the CMAH gene will reliably determine the blood group in cats. Determining a cat’s blood type is important for blood group compatibility and preventing hemolysis during transfusions and in breeding to prevent neonatal isoerythrolysis. Blood type A is the most common among all cat breeds, while blood type C is the most rare, found mainly in Ragdolls, Devon Rex, and British shorthairs. Determining the blood groups of a breeding pair will allow breeders to avoid breeding a queen with B blood group to toms of either blood groups A or C to avoid NI in the kittens. NOTE: The ABC Blood Group System interpretation is based off of three variants (b1, b2 and ac). Other blood group variants have been identified and associated with specific breeds, such as the Ragdoll. Definitive bloodtyping should be done by agglutination or other similar testing methods.
references: Gandolfi B, Grahn RA, Gustafson NA, Proverbio D, Spada E, Adhikari B, Cheng J, Andrews G, Lyons LA, Helps CR. A Novel Variant in CMAH Is Associated with Blood Type AB in Ragdoll Cats. PLoS One. 2016 May 12;11(5):e0154973. Erratum in: PLoS One. 2018 Mar 13;13(3):e0194471. [PubMed PMID: 27171395](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27171395)

Silvestre-Ferreira AC, Pastor J. Feline neonatal isoerythrolysis and the importance of feline blood types. Vet Med Int. 2010;2010:753726. [PubMed PMID: 20631821](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20631821)

Kehl A, Mueller E, Giger U. CMAH genotyping survey for blood types A, B and C (AB) in purpose-bred cats. Anim Genet. 2019 Jun;50(3):303-306. [PubMed PMID: 30854707](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30854707)

_source.name: Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis (HYPP), also known as Burmese hypokalemic periodic polymyopathy is an inherited condition affecting cats. Affected cats display alterations in an enzyme, which plays and important role in regulating sodium and potassium excretion from the kidneys. Thus, these cats lose excessive amounts of potassium in the urine, resulting in potassium deficiency. Affected cats present between two months to two years of age with variable clinical signs associated with abnormally low blood concentrations of potassium including episodic or chronic muscle weakness and muscle pain, muscle tremors, head bobbing, protrusion of shoulder blades, abnormal gait, and downward flexion of the head and neck. Treatment with supplemental potassium will decrease the frequency of clinical symptoms.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the WNK4 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of hypokalemic periodic paralysis. Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the WNK4 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Gandolfi B, Gruffydd-Jones TJ, Malik R, Cortes A, Jones BR, Helps CR, Prinzenberg EM, Erhardt G, Lyons LA. First WNK4-hypokalemia animal model identified by genome-wide association in Burmese cats. PLoS One. 2012;7(12):e53173. [PubMed PMID: 23285264](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23285264)

Malik R, Musca FJ, Gunew MN, Menrath VH, Simpson C, Culvenor J, Grahn RA, Helps C, Lyons LA, Gandolfi B. Periodic hypokalaemic polymyopathy in Burmese and closely related cats: a review including the latest genetic data. J Feline Med Surg. 2015 May;17(5):417-26. [PubMed PMID: 25896241](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25896241)

_source.name: Coat Type - Curly (Devon Rex, Selkirk Rex Type) or Hairless (Sphynx Type) - R Locus (Cat)
bioMutations: Coat Type - Curly (Devon Rex, Selkirk Rex Type) or Hairless (Sphynx Type) - R Locus - hr - c.816+1G>A; g.chrB4:78966685
Coat Type - Curly (Devon Rex, Selkirk Rex Type) or Hairless (Sphynx Type) - R Locus - re - c.1184_1185insAGTTGGAG; g.chrB4:78964456-7894376
Coat Type - Curly (Devon Rex, Selkirk Rex Type) or Hairless (Sphynx Type) - R Locus - SR - c.445-1G>C; g.chrB4:78968269
_source.detailedSummary: The KRT71 gene is known to be involved in coat and hair phenotypes in many mammals. Three variant alleles are known. Two copies of the hr mutation are found in most Sphynx cats and Kohana cats and produces hairlessness. However, about 24% of Sphynx cats studied showed only one copy of the recessive hr mutation, but yet are hairless. This finding supports that there is likely another, unknown mutation in the KRT71 gene that contributes to hairlessness in these cats. Other mutations in the KRT71 gene are known, including the R locus re variant found in the Devon Rex cat.  Two copies of the re mutation is fixed in most Devon Rex cats and produces a curly coat. Outcrossing of Devon Rex cats has demonstrated that cats with only one copy of the re mutation and one copy of the wildtype R gene sequence, do not have curly coats and exhibit typical, straight coats. The Sphynx cat may carry one hairless (hr) mutation and one copy of the re variant; the hr variant is allelic and dominant to the re mutation found in the Devon Rex. The third variant, SR, is found in the Selkirk Rex cat. Selkirk Rex cats with one copy or two copies of the dominant SR variant are curly.  In one study, about 25% of curly Selkirk Rex cats had two copies of the SR variant, while about 75% of curly Selkirk Rex cats had one copy of the SR variant.  All Selkirk Rex cats with straight coats showed two copies of the R wildtype gene sequence. This allelic series shows the following dominance: SR > R > hr > re.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the KRT71 gene will reliably determine the genotypes of cats with various coat phenotypes. The hr variant causing hairlessness in Sphynx cats is known to be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Therefore, Sphynx cats that have two copies of the hr variant are hairless. Cats that carry one copy of the hr variant may also be hairless due to also carrying a copy of the recessive re (R) locus mutation or a copy of an unknown KRT71 gene mutation. Because the SR variant in Selkirk cats is dominant, one or two copies of the SR variant will produce a curly coat. The re variant causing curly coats in Devon Rex cats is known to be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Therefore, Devon Rex cats that are curly will have two copies of the re variant. Overall coat phenotype may also be determined by other mutations in KRT71 or in other genes in the cat genome.
references: Gandolfi B, Outerbridge CA, Beresford LG, Myers JA, Pimentel M, Alhaddad H, Grahn JC, Grahn RA, Lyons LA. The naked truth: Sphynx and Devon Rex cat breed mutations in KRT71. Mamm Genome. 2010 Oct;21(9-10):509-15. [PubMed PMID: 20953787](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20953787)

Gandolfi B, Alhaddad H, Joslin SE, Khan R, Filler S, Brem G, Lyons LA. A splice variant in KRT71 is associated with curly coat phenotype of Selkirk Rex cats. Sci Rep. 2013;3:2000. [PubMed PMID: 23770706](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23770706)

_source.name: Mucopolysaccharidosis Type VII, Variant 1 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Mucopolysaccharidosis VII (MPS VII) is an inherited lysosomal storage disease affecting cats. Affected cats have insufficient activity of the enzyme beta-glucuronidase, which is responsible for breaking down glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). GAGs are an important component many organs including connective tissues.  In affected cats, there is an accumulation of breakdown products in cells causing abnormal growth and function of various organ systems. Clinical signs of MPS VII may present around 12-14 weeks of age and show walking difficulties, enlarged abdomen, unusual facial appearance, corneal clouding, small ears, thickened skin on paws, and possible neurologic conditions including seizures.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the GUSB gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of Mucopolysaccharidosis VII (MPS VII). MPS VII is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the GUSB gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of the mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity with other known mutations in GUSB also resulting in MPS VII. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Fyfe JC, Kurzhals RL, Lassaline ME, Henthorn PS, Alur PR, Wang P, Wolfe JH, Giger U, Haskins ME, Patterson DF, Sun H, Jain S, Yuhki N. _source.name: Polycystic Kidney Disease (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is an inherited renal disease affecting cats. Cats affected with PKD develop fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys, liver and pancreas though cysts in the kidneys are generally the most clinically concerning. Damage caused by progressive cyst formation in the kidneys eventually leads to renal failure in affected cats marked by anorexia, weight loss, vomiting, lethargy, protein in the urine, anemia, excessive urination, dehydration, abnormalities in electrolyte and pH levels, and decreased life expectancy.  Approximately 37% of Persian cats have PKD, making it one of the most common inherited feline diseases.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the PKD1 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is at risk for polycystic kidney disease. Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner meaning that a cat with one copy of the PKD1 mutation is at risk for developing the disease. Given the relatively high frequency of the mutation in certain breeds of cats, it is recommended that cats carrying one copy of the PKD1 mutation are bred to cats with no copies of the mutation to reduce the occurrence of the mutation, rather than removing cats from breeding programs, which might drastically reduce the genetic diversity. Cats that do not inherit the PKD1 mutation are not at an increased risk for developing polycystic kidney disease from this specific mutation. However, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Young AE, Biller DS, Herrgesell EJ, Roberts HR, Lyons LA. Feline polycystic kidney disease is linked to the PKD1 region. Mamm Genome. 2005 Jan;16(1):59-65. [PubMed PMID: 15674734](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15674734)

Lyons LA, Biller DS, Erdman CA, Lipinski MJ, Young AE, Roe BA, Qin B, Grahn RA. Feline polycystic kidney disease mutation identified in PKD1. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2004 Oct;15(10):2548-55. [PubMed PMID: 15466259](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15466259)

_source.name: Mucopolysaccharidosis Type VI (Mild Form) (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Mucopolysaccharidosis type VI (MPSVI) is an inherited lysosomal storage disorder affecting cats. Affected cats have insufficient activity of the enzyme N-acetylgalactosamine-4-sulfatase, also called arylsulfatase B (ARSB), which is responsible for breaking down glycosaminoglycans, specifically dermatan sulfate. In affected cats, there is an accumulation of breakdown products in cells causing variable medical problems from severe to clinically mild symptoms. Cats with the c.1558G>A mutation show a mild phenotype, characterized only by an increase in ARSB activity leading to rapid breakdown of this enzyme.  Cats homozygous for this mutation do not show any other phenotypic symptoms, with normal growth and typical outward appearances, and do not show the joint degeneration common in other forms of MPS VI. This variant appears to have little clinical consequence unless found in the presence of the Siamese ARSB mutation.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the ARSB gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of the lysosomal storage disease, mucopolysaccharidosis type 6 (MPSVI). MPSVI is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the ARSB gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to monitor this mutation in breeding lines, genetic testing is recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity in that there are other breeds, such as the Siamese cat, that have MPSVI due to a different mutation. Cats that are compound heterozygotes for the Siamese mutation and the mild form variant have more severe clinical features than cats that are homozygous for the mild form variant. The presence of heterogeneity demonstrates that a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Yogalingam G, Hopwood JJ, Crawley A, Anson DS. Mild feline mucopolysaccharidosis type VI. Identification of an N-acetylgalactosamine-4-sulfatase mutation causing instability and increased specific activity. J Biol Chem. 1998 May 29;273(22):13421-9. [PubMed PMID: 9593674](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9593674)

Lyons LA, Grahn RA, Genova F, Beccaglia M, Hopwood JJ, Longeri M. Mucopolysaccharidosis VI in cats - clarification regarding genetic testing. BMC Vet Res. 2016 Jul 2;12(1):136. [PubMed PMID: 27370326](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27370326)

Crawley AC, Yogalingam G, Muller VJ, Hopwood JJ. Two mutations within a feline mucopolysaccharidosis type VI colony cause three different clinical phenotypes. J Clin Invest. 1998 Jan 1;101(1):109-19. [PubMed PMID: 9421472](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9421472)

_source.name: Myotonia Congenita (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Myotonia Congenita is an inherited neurologic disorder affecting cats caused by a mutation in the CLCN1 gene. Myotonia congenita is characterized by the inability of the muscles to relax following voluntary contraction. Affected cats also show restricted range of motion of the jaws, drooling, halitosis, gingivitis, protruding and enlarged tongue, stiff and short-strided gait, and lack of startle response.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the CLCN1 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of myotonia congenita. Myotonia congenita is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the CLCN1 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, there may be other causes of this condition in cats and a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Gandolfi B, Daniel RJ, O'Brien DP, Guo LT, Youngs MD, Leach SB, Jones BR, Shelton GD, Lyons LA. A novel mutation in CLCN1 associated with feline myotonia congenita. PLoS One. 2014 Oct 30;9(10):e109926. [PubMed PMID: 25356766](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25356766)

_source.name: Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria, Variant 2 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP) is an inherited metabolic disease in cats. Cats with CEP typically present with orange-brown discoloration of the teeth termed erythrodontia and red-brown discolored urine due to accumulations of blood protein byproducts. Their teeth and bones also fluoresce under a long wave UV light. Cats affected with this type of porphyria frequently display skin hypersensitivity to sunlight resulting in blistering and ulcerative lesions when exposed to sun for prolonged periods. Affected cats may live normal lifespans.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the UROS gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP). CEP is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the UROS gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, this disease shows similar symptoms to other forms of porphyria. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Clavero S, Bishop DF, Giger U, Haskins ME, Desnick RJ. Feline congenital erythropoietic porphyria: two homozygous UROS missense mutations cause the enzyme deficiency and porphyrin accumulation. Mol Med. 2010 Sep-Oct;16(9-10):381-8. [PubMed PMID: 20485863](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20485863)

_source.name: Mucopolysaccharidosis Type VII, Variant 2 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Mucopolysaccharidosis VII (MPSVII) is an inherited lysosomal storage disease affecting cats. Affected cats have insufficient activity of the enzyme beta-glucuronidase, which is responsible for breaking down glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). GAGs are an important component many organs including connective tissues.  In affected cats, there is an accumulation of breakdown products in cells causing abnormal growth and function of various organ systems. Clinical signs of MPS VII may present around 12-14 weeks of age and show walking difficulties, enlarged abdomen, unusual facial appearance, corneal clouding, small ears, thickened skin on paws, and possible neurologic conditions including seizures.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the GUSB gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of Mucopolysaccharidosis VII (MPS VII). MPS VII is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the GUSB gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of the mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity with other known mutations in GUSB also resulting in MPS VII. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Fyfe JC, Kurzhals RL, Lassaline ME, Henthorn PS, Alur PR, Wang P, Wolfe JH, Giger U, Haskins ME, Patterson DF, Sun H, Jain S, Yuhki N. Molecular basis of feline beta-glucuronidase deficiency: an animal model of mucopolysaccharidosis VII. Genomics. 1999 Jun 1;58(2):121-8. [PubMed PMID: 10366443](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10366443)

Gitzelmann R, Bosshard NU, Superti-Furga A, Spycher MA, Briner J, Wiesmann U, Lutz H, Litschi B. Feline mucopolysaccharidosis VII due to beta-glucuronidase deficiency. Vet Pathol. 1994 Jul;31(4):435-43. [PubMed PMID: 7941232](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7941232)

_source.name: Niemann-Pick C1 Disease, Variant 1 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Niemann-Pick C1 disease (NPC) is an inherited lysosomal storage disease affecting cats caused by a mutation in the NPC1 gene. NPC is characterized by neurological signs beginning around 8-12 weeks including progressive ataxia, lack of coordination, head and whole-body tremors, and hepatomegaly. Affected kittens show a birth weight lower than littermates. The disease is progressive with death around 8-10 months of age.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the NPC1 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of Niemann-Pick C1 disease. Niemann-Pick C1 disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the NPC1gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, at least one other mutation in NPC1 is known in cats and, thus, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Brown DE, Thrall MA, Walkley SU, Wenger DA, Mitchell TW, Smith MO, Royals KL, March PA, Allison RW. Feline Niemann-Pick disease type C. Am J Pathol. 1994 Jun;144(6):1412-5. [PubMed PMID: 8203477](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8203477)

Somers KL, Royals MA, Carstea ED, Rafi MA, Wenger DA, Thrall MA. Mutation analysis of feline Niemann-Pick C1 disease. Mol Genet Metab. 2003 Jun;79(2):99-103. [PubMed PMID: 12809639](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12809639)

_source.name: Niemann-Pick C2 Disease (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Niemann-Pick C2 disease (NPC) is an inherited lysosomal storage disease affecting cats caused by a mutation in the NPC2 gene. NPC is characterized by neurological signs including progressive ataxia and lack of coordination. Enlargement of the liver (hepatomegaly) is seen in Niemann-Pick C1 disease, but may be absent from the C2 disease described here. In addition, Niemann-Pick C2 disease may represent a juvenile form of the disease, with symptoms occurring later than that seen in the C1 form of the disease, but within the first year of life.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the NPC2 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of Niemann-Pick C2 disease. Niemann-Pick C2 disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the NPC2 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Zampieri S, Bianchi E, Cantile C, Saleri R, Bembi B, Dardis A. Characterization of a spontaneous novel mutation in the NPC2 gene in a cat affected by Niemann Pick type C disease. PLoS One. 2014 Nov 14;9(11):e112503. [PubMed PMID: 25396745](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25396745)

_source.name: Cystinuria, Type B, Variant 4 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Cystinuria, type B is an inherited inborn error of metabolism affecting cats. The SLC7A9 gene codes for a protein that allows the kidneys to transport cysteine and other amino acids from the urine. Normal kidneys reabsorb the amino acid cystine so that only small amounts pass into the urine, while cats with mutations of both copies of the SLC7A9 gene fail to reabsorb cystine allowing high amounts to pass into the urine, hence the name cystinuria. Males and females are equally affected with excess cysteine in the urine, but obstruction of urine flow by cystine stones is more common in males due to differences in anatomy. Cats with cystinuria often have recurrent inflammation of the urinary tract and if not treated, urinary stones may result in urinary tract infections, blood in the urine, kidney failure and even death.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the SLC7A9 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of cystinuria, type B. Cystinuria, type B is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the SLC7A9 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity with other known mutations in SLC7A9 also resulting in cystinuria. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Mizukami K, Raj K, Osborne C, Giger U. Cystinuria Associated with Different SLC7A9 Gene Variants in the Cat. PLoS One. 2016 Jul 12;11(7):e0159247. [PubMed PMID: 27404572](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27404572)

_source.name: Canine Multiple System Degeneration (Kerry Blue Terrier Type)
_source.commonSymptoms: Canine multiple system degeneration (Kerry Blue Terrier type) is a progressive inherited neurological disease affecting Kerry Blue Terriers. Affected dogs present at 3 to 6 months of age with tremors, abnormal gait and poor balance. Dogs gradually progress to severe gait abnormalities and balance issues, frequent falling, abnormal body posture, abnormal eye movement and eventually, are unable to move. Dogs continue to show normal mental awareness and social behavior despite movement disturbances. Most dogs die due to disease complications or are humanely euthanized by 2 years of age.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the SERAC1 gene in Kerry Blue Terriers will reliably determine whether a dog is a genetic carrier of Canine multiple system degeneration. Canine multiple system degeneration is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in dogs meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier dogs do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected pups. Each pup that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the SERAC1 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected pups, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Kerry Blue Terriers that are not carriers of the mutation have no increased risk of having affected pups.
references: Johnson GS,  Mhlanga-Mutangadura T,  Morava E,  Kozicz T,  Taylor JF,  O’Brien DP,  Schnabel RD. Canine Multiple System Degeneration is Associated with Distinct SERAC1 Mutations in Two Different Dog Breeds [abstract]. Presented at the 63rd Annual Meeting of the American Society of Human Genetics in Boston,  Massachusetts; 2013 Oct 22-26.

references: Dreger DL, Schmutz SM. A SINE insertion causes the black-and-tan and saddle tan phenotypes in domestic dogs. J Hered. 2011 Sep-Oct; 102 Suppl 1:S11-8. [PubMed: 21846741](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21846741)

Dreger DL, Parker HG, Ostrander EA, Schmutz SM. Identification of a mutation that is associated with the saddle tan and black-and-tan phenotypes in Basset Hounds and Pembroke Welsh Corgis. J Hered. 2013 May-Jun; 104(3):399-406. [PubMed: 23519866](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23519866)

_source.name: Multiple Drug Resistance (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Multiple Drug Resistance (MDR) is an inherited susceptibility to adverse reactions following administration of certain medications affecting cats.  This susceptibility is caused by a mutation in the ABCB1 gene known to be involved in drug metabolism. Affected cats can show a variety of neurologic reactions after being administered certain medications including seizures, ataxia, pupillary dilation, tremors, lethargy, and temporary blindness. Drugs that can elicit adverse responses in at-risk cats includes Ivermectin and perhaps others that have not been investigated or observed. Ingestion, topical application or injection of these and other drugs may cause adverse reactions in at-risk cats. In one study, about 5% of cats screened were heterozygous for this mutation.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the ABCB1 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of Multiple Drug Resistance (MDR). MDR is presumed to be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. However, autosomal dominant with incomplete penetrance has not been excluded. Thus, it is not known if carrier cats are at risk for susceptibility to adverse effects after administrating certain drugs.  Therefore, breeding cats who are heterozygote or homozygous for the mutation is not recommended. When a carrier is bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having kittens with two copies of the mutation. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the ABCB1 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, there may be other causes of this condition in cats and a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Mealey KL, Burke NS. Identification of a nonsense mutation in feline ABCB1. J Vet Pharmacol Ther. 2015 Oct;38(5):429-33. doi: 10.1111/jvp.12212. Epub 2015 Feb 9. [PubMed PMID: 25660379](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25660379)

_source.name: Tabby Coat Color Pattern - Mc Locus (Cat)
bioMutations: Tabby Coat Color Pattern - Mc Locus - mc^1 - c.2522 G>A W841X; g. chrA1:94918087
Tabby Coat Color Pattern - Mc Locus - mc^2 - c.682G>A D228N; g. chrA1:94858470
Tabby Coat Color Pattern - Mc Locus - mc^3 - c.176C>A S59X; g. chrA1:94857963
_source.detailedSummary: The LVRN gene impacts feline coat color by effecting the distribution of black or brown eumelanin hairs versus yellow or cream pheomelanin hairs within the coat. The Mc (wildtype) allele is dominant to the mc classic (blotched) allele. Cats that are Mc/Mc or Mc/mc will have Mackerel appearance; whereas mc/mc cats will have a classic (blotched appearance). The expression of Tabby is dependent on a cat being A/A or A/a for the Agouti gene. Cats that are a/a for the Agouti gene do not have tabby coat color/pattern expression. Thus, the cat's coat color is dependent on other genes in the cat genome including loci O, A, E, B and C.
_source.testingTips: The Tabby coat color pattern test evaluates the LVRN gene for the presence of the variant alleles Mc and mc. Genetic testing of the LVRN gene will determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of the mc variant allele (Mc/mc). A normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic trait.
references: Kaelin CB, Xu X, Hong LZ, David VA, McGowan KA, Schmidt-Küntzel A, Roelke ME, Pino J, Pontius J, Cooper GM, Manuel H, Swanson WF, Marker L, Harper CK, van Dyk A, Yue B, Mullikin JC, Warren WC, Eizirik E, Kos L, O'Brien SJ, Barsh GS, Menotti-Raymond M. Specifying and sustaining pigmentation patterns in domestic and wild cats. Science. 2012 Sep 21;337(6101):1536-41. [PubMed PMID: 22997338](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22997338)

_source.name: Dominant White, White Spotting and Gloves - W Locus (Cat)
bioMutations: W or w^s - complex insertions; g. chrB1:162476870-162476871
_source.detailedSummary: The KIT gene impacts feline coat color by modifying the expression of the pigments, eumelanin and phaeomelanin, in the hair resulting in absence of pigmentation. Three variants in the KIT gene have been identified. One variant, w^s, is a full-length insertion of a FERVI element into the KIT gene. The second variant, W, is an insertion of a FERVI-LTR into the KIT gene. The third variant, w^g, is a mutation in KIT that results in white gloves in certain breeds. The variants of the KIT gene are expressed in an autosomal co-dominant manner with W being dominant to and expressed over w^s, w^g, or w, the wildtype allele. Cats with W/W, W/w^s, W/w or W/w^g genotypes show complete penetrance for absence of coat color pigmentation (white coat) and incomplete penetrance for deafness and iris hypopigmentation. Cats that have two copies of w^s or are heterozygous with the wildtype w allele (w^s/w) show variable amounts of white spotting. Cats that have two copies of w^g show limited white on the paws (white gloves). However, for the white spotting phenotype, the cat's base coat color is dependent on other genes in the cat genome including loci A, O, B, E and C. This allelic series shows the following dominance: W > w^s > w > w^g.  In addition, there is heterogeneity in white spotting, as other breeds may show white gloves who do not have the w^g variant.
_source.testingTips: The Paw Print Genetics Dominant White, White Spotting and Gloves coat color test evaluates the KIT gene for the presence of the variant alleles W, w^s, w and w^g. Genetic testing of the KIT gene for these variants will determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of various alleles and whether a cat is at risk for deafness.
references: David VA, Menotti-Raymond M, Wallace AC, Roelke M, Kehler J, Leighty R, Eizirik E, Hannah SS, Nelson G, Schäffer AA, Connelly CJ, O'Brien SJ, Ryugo DK. Endogenous retrovirus insertion in the KIT oncogene determines white and white spotting in domestic cats. G3 (Bethesda). 2014 Aug 1;4(10):1881-91. [PMID: 25085922](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25085922)
Lyons LA. Feline genetics: clinical applications and genetic testing. Top Companion Anim Med. 2010 Nov;25(4):203-12. [PubMed PMID: 21147473](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21147473)

_source.name: Pointed Coat Color and Albinism - C Locus (Cat)
bioMutations: Pointed Coat Color and Albinism - C Locus - c - c.1204C>T; g. chrD1:43974043
Pointed Coat Color and Albinism - C Locus - c^2 - c.975DelC; g. chrD1:44064998
Pointed Coat Color and Albinism - C Locus - c^b - c.715GT; g. chrD1:44075090
Pointed Coat Color and Albinism - C Locus - c^s - c.940G>A; g. chrD1:44065033
_source.detailedSummary: The Tyrosinase gene (TYR) impacts feline coat color through a partial albinism on the torso, leaving dark points on the extremities or complete albinism over the entire body. The C allele is dominant and when present, results in a typical solid coat color. The Siamese pointed variant, c^s, when present in two copies, results in pigmented extremities, with the torso being very light in color. The lack of pigmentation produces blue eyes in this breed. The Burmese pointed variant, c^b, when present in two copies, results in a temperature-sensitive gradient of greatest pigmentation at the points (feet, ears and nose) and less on the torso. The Tonkinese is heterozygous for both recessive variants (c^s/c^b) and has an intermediate phenotype referred to as mink points as compared to the Burmese and Siamese. The Burmese and Singapura breeds appear to be fixed for two copies the c^b allele, while the Siamese, Birman, and Himalayan breeds are fixed for two copies the c^s allele. In addition, there are two variants that cause complete albinism, c and c^2. When present in two copies, cats are completely white and lack any pigmentation. This allelic series shows the following dominance: C > c^s = c^b> c = c^2. A cat's coat color is also dependent on other genes in the cat genome including loci O, B, E and A.
_source.testingTips: The Paw Print Genetics Pointed Coat Color test evaluates the TYR gene for the presence of the variant alleles C, c^s, c^b, c and c^2. Genetic testing of the TYR gene for these variants of TYR will determine whether a dog is a genetic carrier of a Pointed Coat Color variant c^s or c^b (genotype C/c^s or C/c^b) or a genetic carrier of complete albinism variants c or c^2.
references: Lyons LA, Imes DL, Rah HC, Grahn RA. Tyrosinase mutations associated with Siamese and Burmese patterns in the domestic cat (Felis catus). Anim Genet. 2005 Apr;36(2):119-26. [PubMed PMID: 15771720](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15771720)

Schmidt-Küntzel A, Eizirik E, O'Brien SJ, Menotti-Raymond M. Tyrosinase and tyrosinase related protein 1 alleles specify domestic cat coat color phenotypes of the albino and brown loci. J Hered. 2005 Jul-Aug;96(4):289-301. [PubMed PMID: 15858157](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15858157)

Imes DL, Geary LA, Grahn RA, Lyons LA. Albinism in the domestic cat (Felis catus) is associated with a tyrosinase (TYR) mutation. Anim Genet. 2006 Apr;37(2):175-8. [PubMed PMID: 16573534](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16573534)

Abitbol M, Bossé P, Grimard B, Martignat L, Tiret L. Allelic heterogeneity of albinism in the domestic cat. Anim Genet. 2017 Feb;48(1):127-128. [PubMed PMID: 27634063](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27634063)

_source.name: Vitamin D-dependent Rickets, Type IA, Variant 1 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Vitamin D-dependent Rickets is an inherited metabolic disorder affecting cats caused by a mutation in the CYP27B1 gene. Affected cats show reduced skeletal mineralization, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, growth retardation, bone deformities, fractures, delayed secondary dentition, and lethargy. If left to progress, cats may have seizures due to the hypocalcemia and the condition is painful. Cats cannot synthesize vitamin D and must have supplementation in their diets. Cats affected with Vitamin D-dependent Rickets cannot absorb and metabolize vitamin D. Treatments are available to improve the quality of life for affected cats.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the CYP27B1 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of Vitamin D-dependent Rickets. Vitamin D-dependent Rickets is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the CYP27B1 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, there may be other causes of this condition in cats and a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Geisen V, Weber K, Hartmann K. Vitamin D-dependent hereditary rickets type I in a cat. J Vet Intern Med. 2009 Jan-Feb;23(1):196-9. [PubMed PMID: 19138382](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19138382)

_source.name: Cystinuria, Type B, Variant 1 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Cystinuria, type B is an inherited inborn error of metabolism affecting cats. The SLC7A9 gene codes for a protein that allows the kidneys to transport cysteine and other amino acids from the urine. Normal kidneys reabsorb the amino acid cystine so that only small amounts pass into the urine, while cats with mutations of both copies of the SLC7A9 gene fail to reabsorb cystine allowing high amounts to pass into the urine, hence the name cystinuria. Males and females are equally affected with excess cysteine in the urine, but obstruction of urine flow by cystine stones is more common in males due to differences in anatomy. Cats with cystinuria often have recurrent inflammation of the urinary tract and if not treated, urinary stones may result in urinary tract infections, blood in the urine, kidney failure and even death.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the SLC7A9 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of cystinuria, type B. Cystinuria, type B is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the SLC7A9 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity with other known mutations in SLC7A9 also resulting in cystinuria. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Mizukami K, Raj K, Osborne C, Giger U. Cystinuria Associated with Different SLC7A9 Gene Variants in the Cat. PLoS One. 2016 Jul 12;11(7):e0159247. [PubMed PMID: 27404572](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27404572)

_source.name: GM2 Gangliosidosis, Type II (Japanese Domestic Type) (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: GM2 gangliosidosis, type II is an inherited lysosomal storage disorder affecting cats. Affected cats have insufficient activity of the enzyme beta-hexosaminidase B, which is responsible for breaking down specific carbohydrates in the cells. As a result, there is an accumulation of a glycoprotein, GM2 ganglioside, in cells, especially cells of the brain and nervous system. Affected cats typically present with symptoms of neurologic disease around 2 months of age. Initially symptoms begin as head and limb tremors, loss of balance and abnormal eye movements. Symptoms progress to inability to walk around 4 months of age. Hypothermia and difficulty urination may also be seen. Once an affected cat begins to show signs of the disease, the disease progression is rapid and cats will die by 7-10 months of age if not euthanized.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the HEXB gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of GM2 gangliosidosis, type II. GM2 gangliosidosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the HEXB gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity with other known mutations also resulting in GM2 gangliosidosis. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Hasegawa D, Yamato O, Kobayashi M, Fujita M, Nakamura S, Takahashi K, Satoh H, Shoda T, Hayashi D, Yamasaki M, Maede Y, Arai T, Orima H. Clinical and molecular analysis of GM2 gangliosidosis in two apparent littermate kittens of the Japanese domestic cat. J Feline Med Surg. 2007 Jun;9(3):232-7. [PubMed PMID: 17198760](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17198760)

Yamato O, Matsunaga S, Takata K, Uetsuka K, Satoh H, Shoda T, Baba Y, Yasoshima A, Kato K, Takahashi K, Yamasaki M, Nakayama H, Doi K, Maede Y, Ogawa H. GM2-gangliosidosis variant 0 (Sandhoff-like disease) in a family of Japanese domestic cats. Vet Rec. 2004 Dec 4;155(23):739-44. Erratum in: Vet Rec. 2005 Jan 15;156(3):86. _source.name: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (Persian Type) (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Leber congenital amaurosis (or LCA) is a rapidly progressive, early-onset, inherited eye disease affecting cats. LCA occurs as a result of degeneration of both rod and cone type photoreceptor cells of the retina, which are important for vision in dim and bright light respectively. Affected cats begin losing sensitivity to light as early as 2 to 3 weeks of age, progressing to complete loss of vision by 16 to 17 weeks of age. In a study of 707 Persian cats, 22 (3%) were carriers of the AIPL1 mutation. Likewise, in a study of 103 random Exotic cats and 29 Exotic cats from known affected pedigrees, 4 (3%) showed one copy of the AIPL1 mutation. In that same study, 68 Scottish Fold cats were tested and 1 showed one copy of the AIPL1 mutation. Although the frequency of this mutation in the British Shorthair, Burmilla, Himalayan and Selkirk Rex is unknown, this disease test is recommended due to close relatedness of these breeds to Persian cats.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the AIPL1 gene in cats will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA). LCA is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner in cats meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten born to this pairing has a 25% chance of inherited two copies of the mutation and developing the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy of the mutation and being a carrier for this disease. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices and genetic testing should be performed before breeding. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cat that are not carriers of this specific mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens. However, there may be other causes of this condition in cats and a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Alhaddad H, Gandolfi B, Grahn RA, Rah HC, Peterson CB, Maggs DJ, Good KL, Pedersen NC, Lyons LA. Genome-wide association and linkage analyses localize a progressive retinal atrophy locus in Persian cats. Mamm Genome. 2014 Aug;25(7-8):354-62. [PubMed PMID: 24777202](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24777202)

Lyons LA, Creighton EK, Alhaddad H, Beale HC, Grahn RA, Rah H, Maggs DJ, Helps CR, Gandolfi B. Whole genome sequencing in cats, identifies new models for blindness in AIPL1 and somite segmentation in HES7. BMC Genomics. 2016 Mar 31;17:265. [PubMed PMID: 27030474](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27030474)

_source.name: Mucopolysaccharidosis Type VI (Siamese Type) (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Mucopolysaccharidosis type VI (MPS VI) is an inherited lysosomal storage disorder affecting cats. Affected cats have insufficient activity of the enzyme N-acetylgalactosamine-4-sulfatase, also called arylsulfatase B (ARSB), which is responsible for breaking down glycosaminoglycans, specifically dermatan sulfate. In affected cats, there is an accumulation of breakdown products in cells causing abnormal growth and function of many different organ systems. Affected cats show broad flattened face, small ears, diffuse corneal clouding, large forepaws and pectus excavatum.  In addition, affected kittens are smaller than their littermates. The disease is first evident by 6 weeks of age and is progressive resulting in degeneration of joints and fusion of cervical vertebrae.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the ARSB gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of the lysosomal storage disease, mucopolysaccharidosis type 6 (MPSVI). MPSVI is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the ARSB gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity in that there are other breeds that have MPSVI variants due to a different mutation. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Haskins ME, Jezyk PF, Desnick RJ, Patterson DF. Animal model of human disease: Mucopolysaccharidosis VI Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome, Arylsulfatase B-deficient mucopolysaccharidosis in the Siamese cat. Am J Pathol. 1981 Nov;105(2):191-3. [PubMed PMID: 6794375](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6794375)

Yogalingam G, Litjens T, Bielicki J, Crawley AC, Muller V, Anson DS, Hopwood JJ. Feline mucopolysaccharidosis type VI. Characterization of recombinant N-acetylgalactosamine 4-sulfatase and identification of a mutation causing the disease. J Biol Chem. 1996 Nov 1;271(44):27259-65. [PubMed PMID: 8910299](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8910299)

_source.name: Mucopolysaccharidosis Type I (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Mucopolysaccharidosis I (MPSI) is an inherited lysosomal storage disorder affecting cats. Affected cats have insufficient activity of the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase, which is responsible for breaking down glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). GAGs are an important component of tissues throughout the body. In affected cats there is an accumulation of breakdown products in cells causing abnormal growth and function of many different organ systems. Affected cats show progressive lameness, a broad face with depressed nasal bridge, small ears, corneal clouding, and multiple bone dysplasia with a shortened lifespan.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the IDUA gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of the lysosomal storage disease, mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPSI). MPSI is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the IDUA gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, this disease shows genetic heterogeneity in that there are other breeds, such as Siamese cats, that have MPSI but do not have this specific mutation. Therefore, a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease.
references: Haskins ME, Jezyk PF, Desnick RJ, McDonough SK, Patterson DF. Mucopolysaccharidosis in a domestic short-haired cat--a disease distinct from that seen in the Siamese cat. J Am Vet Med Assoc. 1979 Aug 15;175(4):384-7. [PubMed PMID: 115818](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/115818)

He X, Li CM, Simonaro CM, Wan Q, Haskins ME, Desnick RJ, Schuchman EH. Identification and characterization of the molecular lesion causing mucopolysaccharidosis type I in cats. Mol Genet Metab. 1999 Jun;67(2):106-12. [PubMed PMID: 10356309](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10356309)

_source.name: Feline Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency, Type 1 (Cat)
_source.commonSymptoms: Feline Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency, type 1 (FLAD) is an inherited primary immunodeficiency disorder affecting cats caused by a mutation in the ITGB2 gene. Affected cats show omphalitis (infection at the umbilical stump), juvenile periodontitis with loss of teeth, chronic and recurrent bacterial infections with poor response to antibiotic therapy, and impaired wound healing. Affected cats may experience recurring upper respiratory infections, gastroenteritis, anterior uveitis, subcutaneous abscesses, and epidermal sloughing/cellulites with sepsis. With effective medical management of the infections, cats with FLAD may live well into adulthood.
_source.testingTips: Genetic testing of the ITGB2 gene will reliably determine whether a cat is a genetic carrier of feline leukocyte adhesion deficiency, type 1 (FLAD). FLAD is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner meaning that they must receive two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease. In general, carrier cats do not have features of the disease but when bred with another carrier of the same mutation, there is a risk of having affected kittens. Each kitten that is born to a pairing of two carrier parents has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease and a 50% chance of inheriting one copy and being a carrier of the ITGB2 gene mutation. Reliable genetic testing is important for determining breeding practices. In order to eliminate this mutation from breeding lines and to avoid the potential of producing affected kittens, breeding of known carriers to each other is not recommended. Cats that are not carriers of this mutation have no increased risk of having affected kittens for this specific form of the disease. However, there may be other causes of this condition in cats and a normal result does not exclude a different mutation in this gene or any other gene that may result in a similar genetic disease or trait.
references: Bauer TR Jr, Pratt SM, Palena CM, Raj K, Giger U. Feline leukocyte adhesion (CD18) deficiency caused by a deletion in the integrin β(2) (ITGB2) gene. Vet Clin Pathol. 2017 Sep;46(3):391-400. doi: 10.1111/vcp.12526. Epub 2017 Jul 27. [PubMed PMID: 28750142](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28750142)
